{{Review|date=May 2010}} '''[[Grasses]]''' are one of the most abundant floras on all continents except [[Antarctica]]. Their [[Genetic divergence|divergence]] is estimated to have taken place 200 million years ago.<ref name="Wolfe1989">{{cite journal |last=Wolfe |first=H. Kenneth |authorlink= |year=1989 |title=Date of the monocot-dicot divergence estimated from chloroplast DNA sequence data |journal=[[Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences|PNAS]] |volume=86 |issue=16 |pages=6201–6205 |doi=10.1073/pnas.86.16.6201 |url=|pmid=2762323 |pmc=297805|display-authors=etal}}</ref> Humans have intentionally and unintentionally introduced these species to [[North America]] through travel and trade. On the North American plains, [[prairie]]s, [[grassland]]s, and [[meadow]]s at least 11% of grasses are non-native.<ref name="Groom2006">{{cite book |title=Principles of Conservation Biology |last=Groom |first=Martha J. |authorlink= |author2=Meffe, Gary K. |author3=Carroll, C. Ronald |year=2006 |edition=3rd |publisher=Sinauer Associates |location=Sunderland, MA |isbn=0-87893-518-5 |pages= |url= }}</ref> North America is considered a hotspot for many [[:Category:Invasive plant species|invasive plant species]] of grasses, which threatens all of the endangered native grass species and potentially threatens other grass species. Conservation tactics and management policies can help prevent [[invasive species]] from taking over and driving native North American plants to extinction.
==Attributes== Non-native grasses are classified as invasive if they have the following three attributes: # The grass must have a pathway to be delivered to a new location, e.g. boat, shoe, animal, vehicle, feed, contaminated seed, etc. # It is able to tolerate its new environment long enough to establish and reproduce. # It is able to co-exist with native plants. Invasive grasses can outcompete native plants species by manipulating environmental conditions through either chemicals or other physiological factors.
These factors give an upper hand, which will allow the invader to outcompete the native plants. For example, a study conducted in the [[Mojave desert]] of [[California]] by Smith ''et al.'' in 2006, found that invasive grass species increase in areas with higher concentrations of [[carbon dioxide]] (CO<sub>2</sub>), especially in arid conditions which make up 20% of Earth’s terrestrial surface area.<ref name="Smih2006">{{cite journal |last=Smith |first=Stanley D. |authorlink= |year=2000 |title=Elevated CO<sub>2</sub> increases productivity and invasive species' success in an arid ecosystem |journal=[[Nature (journal)|Nature]] |volume=408 |issue=6808 |pages=79–82 |doi=10.1038/35040544 |url=http://www.as.wvu.edu/biology/bio463/Smith%20et%20al%202000.pdf |accessdate= |pmid=11081510 |display-authors=etal}}</ref> Therefore, the annual invasive grasses will outcompete the natives because they use CO<sub>2</sub> to their advantage.
==Impacts== There are many impacts involving invasive grasses in North America, which range from an ecosystem level to a community level to a genetic level. Such impacts influence habitat structure, disturbance regimes, and nutrient cycling.<ref name="Groom2006" /> A successful invasion of a grass may result in new hybrid species, which can have both good and bad results. A good result could be a new species. A bad result could produce a sterile species, which would eventually lead to the extinction of that grass. European [[Cheatgrass]] invading the North American prairies is an example of a disturbance regime because it burns quickly and is very susceptible to fire.<ref name="Groom2006" /> As a result, it gives invasive grasses a [[Head start (positioning)|head start]] in the reproduction process. Another invasive grass impact example, at the ecological level, is [[Cordgrass]] or more specifically ''[[Spartina anglica]]''. This species arose in England as an [[allotetraploid]] of two wild species and was introduced intentionally, to control erosion on the coasts of North America. It now flourishes spreading across the mudflats of the Pacific coast changing them into [[salt marsh]]es, which has tremendous effects on the fauna of the mudflats such as clams, worms, and anemones.<ref name="Thompson1991">{{cite journal |last=Thompson |first=John D. |authorlink= |year=1991 |title=The Biology of an Invasive Plant: What makes ''Spartina anglica'' so successful? |journal=BioScience |volume=41 |issue=6 |pages=393–401 |doi=10.2307/1311746 |jstor= 1311746}}</ref>
==Management== In order to keep North American native grasses from potentially going extinct from invasive grasses, it is important to control or better yet prevent such invasions in the first place. There are many ways to go about this such as controlling species mechanically or physically. This includes hand removal of grasses or by machine. In a five-year study conducted by Wilson ''et al.'' (2001) in Western Oregon, showed that mowing prairies of the invasive grass [[Arrhenatherum elatius]] allowed the native grasses [[Danthonia californica]] and [[Festuca roemeri]] to flourish and out compete the non-natives.<ref name="Wilson2001">{{cite journal |last=Wison |first=Mark V. |authorlink= |author2=Clark, Deborah L. |year=2001 |title=Controlling invasive Arrhenatherum elatius and Promoting Native Prairie Grasses through Mowing |journal=Applied Vegetation Science |volume=4 |issue=1 |pages=129–138 |doi=10.1111/j.1654-109X.2001.tb00243.x |url=http://oregonstate.edu/~wilsomar/PDF/WC_AVS_00.pdf |accessdate= |jstor=1479045 }}</ref> This is an effective method for the control of invasive grasses but it will take many hours of hard manual labor, which could be costly. Using chemicals is an effective way to control non-natives but it is not very ecologically friendly. Chemicals such as herbicides can contaminate waterways or kill other plants in the immediate area. Biological control is the use of other organism to reduce the invader grass. This has been proven to be effective but has also ricocheted back in a negative way. Other options include using multiple approaches at the same time, for example, mowing a specific region of grass land and then using an herbicide to target the invasive. The ultimate way to control invasive grasses in North America is to prevent them from entering in the first place. The first step of this prevention is identifying and regulating the grasses' pathway. After that it needs government assessment and policies to see that these pathways are blocked or regulated.

[[File:Jackalhorn.jpg|thumb|Skull of a [[Sri Lankan jackal]] with a horn]]
The '''Jackal's Horn''' is a boney cone-shaped excrescence which can occasionally grow on the skulls of [[golden jackal]]s. It is associated with magical powers in [[South Asia]]. This horn usually measures half an inch in length, and is concealed by fur.
In the 1800s, the natives of [[Sri Lanka]] called this growth ''narric-comboo'', and both [[Tamil people|Tamil]] and [[Sinhalese people]] traditionally believe it to be a potent [[amulet]] which can grant wishes and reappear to its owner at its own accord when lost. Some Sinhalese believe that the horn can grant the holder invulnerability in any [[lawsuit]].<ref>{{cite book|last1=Tennent|first1=Sir James Emerson||title=Sketches of the natural history of Ceylon|publisher=Longman, Green, Longman, and Roberts|edition=|year=1861|pages=36–37|isbn=|url={{Google books|plainurl=yes|id=qxw3AQAAMAAJ|page=36}}}}</ref>
According to healers and witch doctors in [[Nepal]], a jackal horn can be used to win in [[gambling]] bouts, and ward off evil spirits. The [[Tharu people]] of [[Bardia (Nepal)]] believe that jackal horns are retractible, and only protrude when jackals howl in chorus. A hunter who manages to extract the horn will place it in a silver casket of [[vermilion]] powder, which is thought to give the object sustenance. The Tharu believe that the horn can grant the owner the ability to see in the dark and seduce women.<ref>''Mammals of Nepal: (with reference to those of Pakiatan, Bangladesh, Bhutan and India)'' by Tej Kumar Shrestha, published by Steven Simpson Books, 1997, {{ISBN|0-9524390-6-9}}</ref>
In some areas, the horn is called ''Seear Singhi'' or "Geedhar Singhi" the word "Geedhar" is the [[Urdu]] translation of Jackle and (the [[root word]]s being the [[Persian language|Persian]] "seah" meaning black, and "Singh" which means horn in Hindi and Urdu) and is tied to the necks of children. The horn is sometimes traded by [[low caste]] people, though it is thought that they are in fact pieces of deer antlers sold to the credulous.<ref>''Oral tradition from the Indus International folklore'' by John Frederick Adolphus McNair, Thomas Lambert Barlow, published by Ayer Publishing, 1977, {{ISBN|0-405-10108-2}}</ref>
In [[Bengal]], it is believed that when placed within a [[safe]], jackal horns can increase the amount of money within three-fold. Some criminal elements of the Bengal [[Sansi people|Sansi]] will use fake jackal horns to lull unwitting people into trusting them, and will offer to place these horns into their victim's safe in order to discover its location.<ref>''Encyclopaedia of Indian tribes'' by Padma Shri S.S. Shashi, published by Anmol Publications PVT. LTD., 1994, {{ISBN|81-7041-836-4}}</ref>

'''Juglone''', also called '''5-hydroxy-1,4-naphthalenedione''' ([[IUPAC]]) is an [[organic compound]] with the [[molecular formula]] C<sub>10</sub>H<sub>6</sub>O<sub>3</sub>. In the food industry, juglone is also known as '''C.I. Natural Brown 7''' and '''C.I. 75500'''. It is insoluble in benzene but soluble in [[dioxane]], from which it crystallizes as yellow needles. It is an [[isomer]] of [[lawsone]], which is the staining compound in the [[henna]] leaf.
Juglone occurs naturally in the leaves, roots, husks, fruit ([[fruit anatomy|the epicarp]]), and bark of plants in the [[Juglandaceae]] family, particularly the [[Juglans nigra|black walnut]] (''Juglans nigra''), and is toxic or growth-stunting to many types of plants.<ref>[http://www.wvu.edu/~agexten/hortcult/fruits/blkwalnt.htm Juglone toxicity] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150212041801/http://www.wvu.edu/~agexten/hortcult/fruits/blkwalnt.htm |date=2015-02-12 }}</ref> It is sometimes used as an [[herbicide]], as a [[dye]] for cloth and [[ink]]s, and as a coloring agent for foods and [[cosmetics]].
==History== The harmful effects of [[walnut]] trees on other plants have been observed for at least two millennia. The ancient civilizations of Greece and Rome used the walnut for its [[cytotoxic]] properties as did residents of the American South for easily gathering fish when they threw cut husks into the water with the fish.<ref name="soderquist2">{{cite journal|year=1973|title=Juglone and allelopathy|journal=Journal of Chemical Education|volume=50|issue=11|pages=782–3|bibcode=1973JChEd..50..782S|doi=10.1021/ed050p782|pmid=4747927|last1=Soderquist|first1=Charles J.}}</ref> However, juglone was not isolated until the 1850s. Two men, A. Vogel Jr. and C. Reischauer, were able to isolate the compound from the walnut tree in 1851. The compound was known as nucin at that time. Juglone was then synthesized and characterized for the first time in 1887 by A. Bernthsen and A. Semper.
While at the Virginia Agricultural Experiment Station in 1921, M.T. Cook found that tomato plants in the vicinity of ''Juglans nigra'' were negatively affected, most notably by their wilted leaves.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Cook|first=M.T.|date=1921|title=Wilting caused by walnut trees|url=|journal=Phytopathology|volume=11|pages=346}}</ref> Schneiderhan found that ''Juglans nigra'' and ''Juglans cinerea'' were damaging apple trees in Virginia. The trees that were within an average of 11.9 meters from the walnut trees were found dead. All damaged trees in their vicinity average about 14.3 meters away. In addition, he found that certain local variations of the apple trees tended to be more resistant to the walnuts.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Schneiderhan|first=F.J.|date=1926|title=Apple disease studies in northern Virginia|url=|journal=Virginia Agricultural Experiment Station Bulletin|volume=245|pages=1–35}}</ref>
A.B. Massey observed that the walnut trees in alfalfa fields caused the alfalfa to die away in place of grass. After several other experiments, Massey concluded that the toxic compound found in walnut trees was not easily soluble in water, so the compound in the roots and bark must change chemically after it leaves the tree.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Massey|first=A.B.|date=1928|title=Are nut trees poisonous to other trees and plants?|url=|journal=Flower Grower|volume=15|pages=4}}</ref> It was not until 1928 the compound was identified and confirmed to be [[toxic]] to other plants by E.F. Davis.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=C-nPBYjDAjYC&pg=PA295&lpg=PA295&dq=massey+are+nut+trees+poisonous#v=onepage&q=juglone&f=false|title=The History of Allelopathy|last=Willis|first=Rick J.|date=2007-10-12|publisher=Springer Science & Business Media|isbn=9781402040931|language=en}}</ref>
After the scientific news of the harm walnut trees caused certain crops and trees, there was backlash from the scientific community to refute these findings. On one account, A.G. Miller claimed that the trees that Schneiderhan observed to be harming the apple trees in Virginia were not in fact walnut trees.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Miller|first=A.G.|date=1926|title=Walnuts and apples|url=|journal=Farm Journal|volume=1926 (July)|pages=17}}</ref>
By 1942, B.I. Brown showed that tomato and alfalfa germination and seedling growth was slowed down by being in contact with pieces of walnut roots, adding further scientific evidence to the biological damage of juglone.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Brown|first=B.I.|date=1942|title=Injurious influence of bark of black walnut on seedlings of tomato and alfalfa|url=|journal=North Nut Growers Association Annual Report|volume=33|pages=97–102}}</ref>
The walnut tree has historically been used within the field of [[traditional medicine]]. In America during the early 1900s, doctors prescribed juglone for the treatment of various [[skin diseases]].<ref name="strugstad2">{{cite journal|date=2012|title=A Summary of Extraction, Synthesis, Properties, and Potential Uses of Juglone: A Literature Review|journal=Journal of Ecosystems and Management|volume=13|issue=3|pages=72–82|author=M. Strugstad}}</ref>
==Chemistry==
===Synthesis=== Juglone is derived by oxidation of the nontoxic hydrojuglone, [[1,5-Dihydroxynaphthalene|1,5-dihydroxynaphthalene]], after enzymatic hydrolysis.<ref name=Ullmann>Gerald Booth "Naphthalene Derivatives" in ''Ullmann's Encyclopedia of Industrial Chemistry'', 2005, Wiley-VCH, Weinheim. {{DOI|10.1002/14356007.a17_009}}.</ref> It can be also be obtained by oxidations of 5,8-dihydroxy-1-tetralone with [[silver(I) oxide|silver oxide]] (Ag<sub>2</sub>O), [[manganese dioxide]] (MnO<sub>2</sub>), or [[2,3-dichloro-5,6-dicyano-1,4-benzoquinone]] (DDQ).<ref name=khalafy>{{cite journal |author1=J. Khalafy |author2=J.M. Bruce | date = 2002 | title = Oxidative dehydrogenation of 1-tetralones: Synthesis of juglone, naphthazarin, and α-hydroxyanthraquinones | journal = Journal of Sciences, Islamic Republic of Iran | volume =13 | issue = 2 | pages = 131–139}}</ref>
===Extraction=== Juglone has been extracted from the husk of [[walnut]] fruit of which it contains 2-4% by fresh weight.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Combes|first1=M. R.|title=Bulletin de la Société chimique de France|journal=Combes, Bull. Soc. Chim.|date=1907|volume=1|issue=4|pages=800–816|url=https://archive.org/stream/bulletindelasoc181frangoog#page/n810/mode/2up|accessdate=14 October 2016|language=French}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Cosmulescu|first1=Sina Niculina|last2=Trandafir|first2=Ion|last3=Achim|first3=Gheorghe|last4=Botu|first4=Mihai|last5=Baciu|first5=Adrian|last6=Gruia|first6=Marius|title=Phenolics of Green Husk in Mature Walnut Fruits|journal=Notulae Botanicae Horti Agrobotanici Cluj-Napoca|date=15 June 2010|volume=38|issue=1|pages=53–56|doi=10.15835/nbha3814624|url=http://www.notulaebotanicae.ro/index.php/nbha/article/view/4624|accessdate=11 October 2016|language=en|issn=1842-4309|doi-broken-date=2018-09-10}}</ref>
=== Degradation === Before oxidization, juglone exists in plants such as walnuts in the form of colorless [[hydroxyjuglone]], with both O groups replaced with OH groups. This is rapidly oxidized to juglone once exposed to air. The evidence that hydroxyjuglone is readily degraded is most apparent in the color change of walnut hulls from yellow to black after being freshly cut.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Gries|first=G.A.|date=1943|title=Juglone - the active agent in walnut toxicity|url=|journal=Northern Nut Growers Association Annual Report|volume=34|pages=52–55}}</ref>
Indigenous bacteria found in the soil of black walnut roots, most notably ''[[Pseudomonas putida]]'' J1, are able to metabolize juglone and use it as their primary source of energy and carbon.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Schmidt|first=S.K.|date=1988|title=Degradation of juglone by soil bacteria|url=|journal=Journal of Chemical Ecology|volume=14|issue=7|pages=1561–1571|doi=10.1007/bf01012522|pmid=24276429}}</ref> Because of this, juglone is not so active as a cytotoxin in well-aerated soils.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Fisher|first=R.F.|date=1987|title=Juglone inhibits pine growth under certain moisture regimes|url=|journal=Soil Sci. Soc. Am. J.|volume=42|pages=801–803}}</ref>
==Biological effects== Juglone is an [[allelopathy|allelopathic]] compound, a substance that is produced by a plant to stunt the growth of another. The [[germination]] process of plants is less affected by the compound than the growth of the root and stem systems. In below average concentrations, it has actually increased the rate of germination in some [[coniferous]] seeds.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Rietveld|first=W J|date=1983|title=Allelopathic effects of juglone on germination and growth of several herbaceous and woody species|url=|journal=J. Chem. Ecol.|volume=9|issue=2|pages=295–308|doi=10.1007/bf00988047|pmid=24407348|citeseerx=10.1.1.550.5739}}</ref>
Juglone exerts its effect by [[enzyme inhibitor|inhibiting]] certain [[enzyme]]s needed for metabolic function. This in turn inhibits the effects of respiration of mitochondria and inhibits photosynthesis found in common crops such as [[maize]] and [[Soybean|soy]] at juglone concentrations that are at or below those common in nature.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Koeppe|first=D.E.|date=1972|title=Some reactions of isolated corn mitochondria influenced by juglone|url=|journal=Physiol. Plant.|volume=27|pages=89–94|doi=10.1111/j.1399-3054.1972.tb08573.x}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hejl|first=A.M.|last2=Einhellig|first2=F.A.|last3=Rasmussen|first3=J.A.|date=1993|title=Effects of juglone on growth, photosynthesis, and respiration|url=|journal=J. Chem. Ecol.|volume=19|issue=3|pages=559–568|doi=10.1007/bf00994325|pmid=24248956}}</ref> In addition to these inhibitions, juglone has been shown to alter the relationship between plants and water because of its effect on [[stoma]]tal functioning.<ref>Einhelling F.A. 1986 Mechanisms and modes of action of allelochemicals. ''In The Science of Allelopathy.'' Eds. A R Putnam and C S Tang. pp 171–188. John Wiley & Sons, New York</ref>
The rise in popularity of [[Agroforestry#Alley_cropping|alley cropping]] with black walnut trees and maize in the temperate Midwest, due to the high value of black walnut trees, has led to certain studies being conducted about the particular relationship between the two species. Research has shown that juglone affects the yield of maize crops; however, the practice of [[pruning]] and usage of [[root barrier]]s greatly reduce these effects.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/225979920|title=Allelopathy in black walnut (Juglans nigra L.) alley cropping. I. Spatio-temporal variation in soil juglone in a black walnut-corn (Zea mays L.) alley cropping system in the midwestern USA (PDF Download Available)|website=ResearchGate|language=en|access-date=2017-04-20}}</ref>
A number of plants and trees are resistant to juglone including some species of [[maple]] (''Acer''), [[birch]] (''Betula''), and [[beech]] (''Fagus'').
It is highly toxic to many insect herbivores. However, some of them, example ''[[Actias luna]]'' (Luna moth), are capable of detoxification of juglone (and related naphthoquinones) to non-toxic 1,4,5-trihydroxy[[naphthalene]]. It has also shown [[anthelmintic]] (expelling parasitic worms) activity on mature and immature ''Hymenolepis nana'' in mice.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Dama L.B. |author2=Jadhav B.V. | date = 1997 | title = Anthelmintic effect of Juglone on mature and Immature Hymenolepis nana in mice | journal = Riv. Di Parassitol. | volume = 2 | pages = 301–302}}</ref> Napthoquinonic compounds also exhibit antimicrobial activity.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Dama L.B. |author2=Poul B.N. |author3=Jadhav B.V. | date = 1998 | title = Antimicrobial activity of Napthoquinonic compounds | journal = J. Ecotoxicol.Environ. Monit. | volume = 8 | pages = 213–215}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author1=Dama L.B. |author2=Poul B.N. |author3=Jadhav B.V |author4=Hafeez MD. | date = 1999 | title = Effect of "Juglone" on Development of the plant parasitic nematode (Meloidogyne Spp.) on Arachis hypogaea L | journal = J. Ecotoxicol. Environ. Monit. | volume = 9 | pages = 73–75}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | author = Dama L.B. | title = Effect of naturally occurring napthoquinones on root- knot nematode Meloidogyne spp | journal = Indian Phytopathology | volume = 55 | issue = 1 | pages = 67–69 | date = 2002}}</ref>
==Uses== Juglone is occasionally used as a [[herbicide]]. Traditionally, juglone has been used as a natural dye for clothing and fabrics, particularly [[wool]], and as ink. Because of its tendency to create dark orange-brown stains, juglone has also found use as a coloring agent for foods and cosmetics, such as [[hair dyes]].
Juglone is currently being studied for its anticancer properties.<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 19726363 | volume=29 | issue=6 | title=Effect of juglone on the ultrastructure of human liver cancer BEL-7402 cells | date=Jun 2009 | journal=Nan Fang Yi Ke da Xue Xue Bao | pages=1208–11|url=http://xuebao.jlu.edu.cn/yxb/EN/abstract/abstract4445.shtml| author1=Chen | first1=L | last2=Na-Shun | first2=B. Y. | last3=Zhang | first3=J | last4=Yu | first4=J | last5=Gu | first5=W. W. }}</ref> It has been shown to decrease the probability of intestinal tumors in rats that have been exposed to carcinogens.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Sugie | first1 = S. | last2 = Okamoto | first2 = K. | last3 = Rahman | first3 = K. M. W. | last4 = Tanaka | first4 = T. | last5 = Kawai | first5 = K. | last6 = Yamahara | first6 = J. | last7 = Mori | first7 = H. | year = 1998 | title = Inhibitory effects of plumbagin and juglone on azoxymethane-induced intestinal carcinogenesis in rats | url = | journal = Cancer Lett | volume = 127 | issue = | pages = 177–183 | doi=10.1016/s0304-3835(98)00035-4}}</ref> One of the potential pathways through which juglone achieves its anticancer properties is through the formation of the [[semiquinone]] radical; the semiquinone radical causes [[superoxide]] anion radicals to form which can lead to [[apoptosis]] when present in large concentrations.<ref name=ji>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1016/j.etp.2009.09.010| pmid = 19815401| title = Juglone-induced apoptosis in human gastric cancer SGC-7901 cells via the mitochondrial pathway| journal = Experimental and Toxicologic Pathology| volume = 63| issue = 1–2| pages = 69–78| year = 2011| last1 = Ji| first1 = Yu-Bin| last2 = Qu| first2 = Zhong-Yuan| last3 = Zou| first3 = Xiang}}</ref> This conversion from juglone to semiquinone radical that causes the superoxide anion radical to form takes place in the mitochondria as well as the [[cytosol]].<ref name=inbaraj>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1021/tx034132s| pmid = 14727919| title = Cytotoxic Action of Juglone and Plumbagin: A Mechanistic Study Using HaCaT Keratinocytes| journal = Chemical Research in Toxicology| volume = 17| issue = 1| pages = 55–62| year = 2004| last1 = Inbaraj| first1 = J. Johnson| last2 = Chignell| first2 = Colin F.}}</ref>
===Spectral data=== The spectral data for juglone confirms its bicyclic structure which contains a hydroxyl group as well as two carbonyl groups. The IR for juglone shows peaks at 3400 cm-1, 1662 cm-1, and 1641 cm-1 which are characteristic of the hydroxyl and carbonyl groups.<ref name=suchard>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1016/j.tet.2005.11.021| title = Photooxygenations of 1-naphthols: An environmentally friendly access to 1,4-naphthoquinones| journal = Tetrahedron| volume = 62| issue = 7| pages = 1467| year = 2006| last1 = Suchard| first1 = Oliver| last2 = Kane| first2 = Ronan| last3 = Roe| first3 = Bernard J.| last4 = Zimmermann| first4 = Elmar| last5 = Jung| first5 = Christian| last6 = Waske| first6 = Prashant A.| last7 = Mattay| first7 = Jochen| last8 = Oelgemöller| first8 = Michael}}</ref> The <sup>13</sup>C NMR shows 10 peaks indicating the correct number of unique carbon atoms in the molecule as well as peaks at 160.6 ppm, 183.2 ppm, and 189.3 ppm for the carbon attached to the hydroxyl group and the two carbons part of the two carbonyl groups.<ref name="suchard"/><!-- <sup>1</sup>H n.m.r (300 MHz) δ 6.96 (s, H-2 + H-3), 7.26 (m, H-6), 7.62 (m, H-7+H-8), 11.91 (s; 5-OH); ν<sub>max</sub> (film) 3065 b, 1665 s, 1594 m, 1451s, 1363 s, 1290 vs, 1226 s cm<sup>−1</sup>; and m/z (EI) 176[(M + 2)<sup>+</sup>, 10.8], 174 (M+, 100), 173 (21.9), 146 (15.9), 120 (29.6), 118 (48.8), 92 (31.4).--><ref name=khalafy/>

<onlyinclude><!-- See [[Wikipedia_talk:Featured_lists#Proposed_change_to_all_featured_lists]] for an explanation of this and other inclusion tags below -->[[Image:Delaware hurricane tracks.jpg|right|thumb|300px|Track map of all tropical cyclones that passed over Delaware from 1851 to 2005]] The following is a '''list of tropical cyclones that affected the U.S. state of Delaware'''. Since reliable records began, no [[tropical cyclone]] has struck the state while maintaining [[Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale|hurricane intensity]], and only two storms since 1851 caused hurricane-force winds in the state.</onlyinclude><ref name="climo">{{cite web|author=Blake, Rappaport, Jarrell, & Landsea|year=2005|title=Frequently Requested Hurricane Facts|publisher=NOAA|accessdate=2006-07-23|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/Landsea/dcmifinal2.pdf}}</ref> The state often experiences the direct effects of landfalling [[North Atlantic tropical cyclone]]s and from the remnants of some [[Pacific hurricane|Pacific storms]], such as rainfall or strong winds, as well as the effects of storms that remain offshore, such as rip currents or heavy surf. Since 1749, at least 111 tropical cyclones, some of which had become [[extratropical cyclone|extratropical]], have affected the state, including 21 which passed over the state.
==List of tropical cyclones==
===Pre-1900=== <onlyinclude> *October 21, 1749- A hurricane is observed over [[Delaware]].<ref name="17001850chron">{{cite web|author=Michael Chenoweth|year=2006|title=A Reassessment of Historical Atlantic Basin Cyclones; 1700–1855|publisher=NOAA|accessdate=2006-07-23|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/hurdat/Chenoweth/chenoweth06.pdf}}</ref> *Fall, 1783- Nine large ships crash near [[Cape Henlopen]] during a hurricane, killing several people.<ref name="nhcposs25">{{cite web|author1=Edward N. Rappaport |author2=Jose Fernandez-Partagas |lastauthoramp=yes|year=1996|title=The Deadliest Atlantic Tropical Cyclones, 1492–1996|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=2006-07-23|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/pastdeadlyapp2.shtml?}}</ref> *September 2, 1785- A hurricane causes 181 deaths in the state. Whether or not it made landfall is unknown.<ref name="nhcdeadliest">{{cite web|author1=Edward N. Rappaport |author2=Jose Fernandez-Partagas |lastauthoramp=yes|year=1996|title=The Deadliest Atlantic Tropical Cyclones, 1492–1996|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=2006-07-23|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/pastdeadlyapp1.shtml?}}</ref> *September 3–5, 1815- A [[1815 North Carolina hurricane|tropical storm]] passes over extreme southeastern Delaware. Effects, if any, are unknown.<ref name="1815track">{{cite web|author=HHIT Project|year=2005|title=Track map for 1815 hurricane|accessdate=2006-07-23|url=http://myweb.fsu.edu/jelsner/temp/HHITProject/HHITyears/1815/storm1_track.pdf}}</ref> *September 3, 1821- The eye of the [[1821 Norfolk and Long Island hurricane|Norfolk and Long Island Hurricane]] moves directly over Cape Henlopen for 30 minutes.<ref name="1821hurr">{{cite web|author=Ho|year=2005|title=1821 Hurricane information|accessdate=2006-07-23|url=http://myweb.fsu.edu/jelsner/temp/HHITProject/HHITyears/1821/storm1_pt1_ho.pdf}}</ref> *August 17, 1830- A hurricane that passes to the east of the state capsizes three ships along the Delaware capes.<ref name="1830hurr">{{cite web|author=Ludlum|year=2005|title=1830 Hurricane information|accessdate=2006-07-23|url=http://myweb.fsu.edu/jelsner/temp/HHITProject/HHITyears/1821/storm1_pt1_ho.pdf}}</ref></onlyinclude> *August 28–31, 1839- Several ships are washed ashore in [[Lewes, Delaware|Lewes]] during a hurricane that parallels the [[East Coast of the United States]].<ref name="1839hurr">{{cite web|author=Ludlum|year=2005|title=1839 Hurricane information|accessdate=2006-07-23|url=http://myweb.fsu.edu/jelsner/temp/HHITProject/HHITyears/1839/storm1_ludlum.pdf}}</ref> *September 8, 1846- Rough seas and troubled shipping in the [[Delaware Bay]] are caused by a hurricane offshore.<ref name="1846hurr">{{cite web|author=Ludlum|year=2005|title=1846 Hurricane information|accessdate=2006-07-23|url=http://myweb.fsu.edu/jelsner/temp/HHITProject/HHITyears/1846/storm1_ludlum.pdf}}</ref> *October 13, 1846- A [[Great Havana Hurricane of 1846|hurricane]] crosses over northwestern Delaware, with its powerful winds toppling the steeple of a church in [[New Castle, Delaware|New Castle]]. The hurricane's storm surge, which is considered the worst in 70 years, floods lowlands in the northern portion of the state.<ref name="1846hurr2">{{cite web|author=Ludlum|year=2005|title=1846 Hurricane information (2)|accessdate=2006-07-23|url=http://myweb.fsu.edu/jelsner/temp/HHITProject/HHITyears/1846/storm2_pt3_ludlum.pdf}}</ref> *July 18, 1850- Rough seas are reported along the Delaware Bay due to a hurricane passing to the west of the state.<ref name="1850hurr">{{cite web|author=Ludlum|year=2005|title=1850 Hurricane information|accessdate=2006-07-23|url=http://myweb.fsu.edu/jelsner/temp/HHITProject/HHITyears/1850/storm1_ludlum.pdf}}</ref> *August 4, 1850- A hurricane crosses the state, causing gale-force winds along the coast.<ref name="1850hurr2">{{cite web|author=Ludlum|year=2005|title=1850 Hurricane information (2)|accessdate=2006-07-23|url=http://myweb.fsu.edu/jelsner/temp/HHITProject/HHITyears/1850/storm2_pt2_ludlum.pdf}}</ref> *September 8, 1850- Many ships report calls of distress due to powerful winds from a hurricane.<ref name="1850hurr2" /> *August 20, 1856- A tropical storm parallels the coastline of the [[Delmarva Peninsula]], though impact, if any, is unknown.{{Atlantic hurricane best track}} *September 28, 1861- After weakening from a hurricane, a tropical storm moves northward through Delaware. Effects are unknown.<ref name="HURDAT"/> *September 19, 1863- A tropical storm crosses the state from south to north. Effects are unknown.<ref name="HURDAT"/> *October 28, 1872- A tropical storm crosses the state, with no known effects.<ref name="HURDAT"/> *September 29, 1874- With winds of 70 mph (115 km/h), a tropical storm moves across Delaware.<ref name="HURDAT"/> *October 5, 1877- An extratropical storm, once a [[Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale|Category 3 Hurricane]], crosses the state, causing several ship wrecks in the [[Chesapeake Bay|Chesapeake]] and Delaware Bays.<ref name="1877mwr">{{cite web|author=U.S. War Department|year=1877|title=1877 Monthly Weather Review|accessdate=2006-07-23|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/general/lib/lib1/nhclib/mwreviews/1877.pdf}}</ref> *October 23, 1878- The [[Gale of 1878]], which makes landfall on [[North Carolina]], brings hurricane-force winds to the entire state of Delaware. The storm drops over 3 inches (75 mm) of rainfall in the northern portion of the state, flooding portions of [[Wilmington, Delaware|Wilmington]]. The winds and rain from the storm damages or destroys many houses statewide. The flooding washes out railroads, roads, and bridges, and destroys many carriages in [[Dover, Delaware|Dover]]. Crop damage is severe, as well. The strong winds wreck four ships, in total killing 14. A 7-foot (2.1 m) storm surge in Lewes drowns four when they can't escape the rising waters. Beach erosion is severe, as well. Across Delaware, the hurricane kills 18 and causes $45,000 in damage (1878 USD, $1 million 2008 USD).<ref name="1878cane">{{cite web|author=Roth and Cobb|year=2000|title=Gale of '78|publisher=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center|accessdate=2006-07-23|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/research/roth/galeof78.htm}}</ref> It is one of only three storms to bring hurricane-force winds to the state.<ref name="climo"/> *August 18, 1879- A Category 2 hurricane parallels the Delmarva Peninsula after striking [[North Carolina]], though effects, if any, are unknown.<ref name="HURDAT"/> *September 23, 1882- A tropical storm crosses over southeastern Delaware. Impact, if any, is unknown.<ref name="HURDAT"/> *June 23, 1886- A tropical depression moves across the state, with no known impact.<ref name="HURDAT"/> *September 11, 1888- An extratropical storm crosses the state.<ref name="HURDAT"/> *September 9–12, 1889- After moving northwestward for much of its life, a large hurricane approaches the East Coast of the United States, moves southwestward, and dissipates to the east of [[Virginia]]. The hurricane causes severe waves and a powerful storm surge, damaging life guard stations and wrecking or washing 31 vessels ashore. The death toll "would probably exceed 40", while damage totals $570,000 (1889 USD, $13.6 million 2008 USD).<ref name="1889mwr">{{cite web|author=Monthly Weather Review|year=1889|title=1889 Monthly Weather Review|accessdate=2006-07-23|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/general/lib/lib1/nhclib/mwreviews/1889.pdf}}</ref> *October 10, 1894- A hurricane passes to the southeast of the state.<ref name="HURDAT"/> *October 23–26, 1897- A tropical storm moving northward prompts officials to issue hurricane warnings from [[North Carolina]] through [[New York (state)|New York]], though the storm unexpectedly executes a loop and moves out to sea.<ref name="1896mwr">{{cite web|author=Monthly Weather Review|year=1897|title=Monthly Weather Review for 1897|accessdate=2006-07-23|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/general/lib/lib1/nhclib/mwreviews/1897.pdf}}</ref>
===1900-1949=== *September 16, 1903- The '''[[1903 Vagabond hurricane|Vagabond Hurricane]]''' parallels the Delmarva Peninsula coastline and makes landfall on southern [[New Jersey]], bringing [[Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale|Category 1]] hurricane-force winds to Delaware. It is one of only three storms to bring hurricane-force winds to the state.<ref name="climo"/> The hurricane washes a schooner ashore, killing five.<ref name="19011950va">{{cite web|author=Roth & Cobb|year=2001|title=Virginia Hurricane History from 1901 to 1950|publisher=NOAA|accessdate=2006-07-25|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/research/roth/vaerly20hur.htm}}</ref> *September 15, 1904- A tropical storm becomes extratropical as it moves across the state,<ref name="HURDAT"/> killing eight people when a tugboat capsizes.<ref>{{cite news|author=Staff Writer|date=1904-09-16|title=Eight Men Lost by Sinking of Tug|publisher=The Hartford Courant|accessdate=2008-06-19|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/courant/access/774137212.html?dids=774137212:774137212&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:AI&date=Sep+16%2C+1904&author=&pub=The+Hartford+Courant&desc=EIGHT+MEN+LOST+BY+SINKING+OF+TUG&pqatl=google}}</ref> *October 24, 1923- Once a tropical storm in the [[Caribbean Sea]], an extratropical storm moves northwestward through Delaware, causing no known damage.<ref name="HURDAT"/> *August 24, 1933- After making landfall on the [[Outer Banks]], the '''[[1933 Chesapeake Potomac hurricane]]''' passes through [[Virginia]] and [[Maryland]]. Higher than normal tides washes out about 1 square mile (2.6 km²) of beaches along the Delaware coastline, while strong winds cause $150,000 in damage (1933 USD, $2.5 million 2008 USD).<ref name="1933mwr">{{cite web|author=R. Hanson Weightman|year=1933|title=August 1933 Monthly Weather Review|publisher=US Weather Bureau|accessdate=2006-07-25|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/general/lib/lib1/nhclib/mwreviews/1933.pdf}}</ref> *September 18, 1936- A Category 2 hurricane parallels the Delmarva Peninsula, causing higher than usual tides at [[Lewes, Delaware|Lewes]].<ref name="deltid">{{cite web|author=K.W. Ramsey|year=2000|title=Tides of Record for Breakwater Harbor, Lewes, Delaware|publisher=Delaware Geological Survey|accessdate=2006-07-25|url=http://www.udel.edu/dgs/Geology/breakwatertides.html}}</ref> *September 21, 1938- The '''[[New England Hurricane of 1938]]''' produces moderate to heavy amounts of precipitation across the entire state.<ref name="1938nerain">{{cite web|author=David Roth|year=2006|title=Rainfall Information for 1938 Long Island Hurricane|publisher=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center|accessdate=2007-04-14|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/longislandexpress1938.html}}</ref> *August 20, 1939- The remnants of a hurricane that struck the [[Florida Panhandle]] drop heavy rainfall across the state.<ref name="1939mwr">{{cite web|author=I. R. Tannehill|year=1938|title=September 1939 Monthly Weather Review|publisher=US Weather Bureau|accessdate=2006-07-25|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/general/lib/lib1/nhclib/mwreviews/1939.pdf}}</ref> *October 1, 1943- A tropical storm that makes landfall on [[Maryland]] passes over western Delaware, though effects, if any, are unknown.<ref name="HURDAT"/> *August 3, 1944- A tropical storm crosses the state, causing no known effects.<ref name="1944mwr">{{cite web|author=H. C. Woolard|year=1944|title=1944 Monthly Weather Review|publisher=US Weather Bureau|accessdate=2006-07-25|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/general/lib/lib1/nhclib/mwreviews/1944.pdf}}</ref> *September 14, 1944- The '''[[1944 Great Atlantic Hurricane]]''' parallels the [[East Coast of the United States]] just offshore, causing damage to 1,800 homes and 850 other buildings. No fatalities are reported in the state.<ref name="1944mwr"/>
===1950–1974=== *September 1, 1952- '''[[Hurricane Able (1952)|Tropical Storm Able]]''' passes a short distance to the northwest of the state. Damage, if any, is unknown.<ref name="HURDAT"/> *August 31 & September 11, 1954- '''[[Hurricane Carol|Hurricanes Carol]] and [[Hurricane Edna|Edna]]''' parallel the Delmarva Peninsula offshore, causing no known damage.<ref name="HURDAT"/> *October 15, 1954- '''[[Hurricane Hazel]]''' passes to the west of the state, bringing wind gusts of over 100 mph (160 km/h).<ref name="nchis">{{Cite web|author=Jay Barnes|title=North Carolina's Hurricane History|accessdate=2006-07-26|url=http://www.ibiblio.org/uncpress/hurricanes/nc_hazel.html|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060319163834/http://www.ibiblio.org/uncpress/hurricanes/nc_hazel.html|archivedate=2006-03-19|df=}}</ref> The hurricane causes at least one death in the state.<ref name="floyd99">{{cite web|author=National Climatic Data Center|year=1999|title=Event Report for Hurricane Floyd|accessdate=2006-07-29|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~357393|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110519215747/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~357393|archivedate=2011-05-19|df=}}</ref> *August, 1955- '''[[Hurricane Connie|Hurricanes Connie]] and [[Hurricane Diane|Diane]]''' pass to the west of the state during the month, bringing over 8 inches (200 mm) of rain to the [[Delaware Valley]] and causing record-breaking flooding.<ref name="delval">{{cite web|author=Nicholas DiGiovanni|year=2005|title=Back-to-back storms in 1955 unleashed havoc along Delaware River|publisher=[[The Hunterdon County Democrat]]|accessdate=2006-07-26|url=http://www.nj.com/news/hunterdon/index.ssf?/news/hunterdon/stories/storms_081105.html}}</ref> *September 19, 1955- '''[[Hurricane Ione]]''' makes landfall in [[North Carolina]], with its outer moisture producing light rainfall across the state.<ref name="ionerain">{{cite web|author=David Roth|year=2006|title=Rainfall Information for Hurricane Ione|publisher=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center|accessdate=2007-04-14|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/ione1955.html}}</ref> *September 28, 1956 – The remnants of '''[[Hurricane The strong winds and waves cause beach erosion, as well.<ref name="dennis99">{{cite web|author=National Climatic Data Center|year=1999|title=Hurricane Dennis Event Report|accessdate=2006-07-29|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~357390|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110519215804/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~357390|archivedate=2011-05-19|df=}}</ref> *September 16, 1999- '''[[Hurricane Floyd|Tropical Storm Floyd]]''' crosses over the southeastern portion of the state. The storm produces strong wind gusts of up to 64 mph (103 km/h) in [[Sussex County, Delaware|Sussex County]] and heavy rainfall peaking at 10.58 inches (269 mm) in [[Greenwood, Delaware|Greenwood]], a 24-hour state record. The flooding, which exceeds the 100-year flood return period, kills two and causes record-breaking river levels across the state. Hundreds of roads, railroad lines, and bridges are closed or destroyed, trapping dozens due to flooded vehicles. The winds uproot hundreds of trees, leaving 25,000 homes and businesses without power for 3 days. Floyd damages 171 homes, 44 severely, and destroys 33 in [[New Castle County, Delaware|New Castle County]]. Damage is minimal near the ocean, and amounts to minor beach erosion and tidal flooding. Throughout the state, damage totals to $8.42 million (1999 USD, $10.9 million 2008 USD). In response to the damage, President [[Bill Clinton]] declares the state as a disaster area, which allows for federal funding to rebuild and cleanup after the storm.<ref name="floyd99"/> *October 17, 1999- Moisture from '''[[Hurricane Irene (1999)|Hurricane Irene]]''' produces rainfall across the state, ranging from 1 to 4 inches (25 to 100 mm). ===2000-2008=== *September 19, 2000- The remnants of '''[[Hurricane Gordon (2000)|Hurricane Gordon]]''' produce heavy rainfall for a few hours, resulting in rainfall totals of up to 1.82 inches (46 mm) in [[Newark, Delaware|Newark]]. The precipitation causes the [[Christina River]] to crest at 9.13 feet (2.78 m) above flood stage, though damage is minimal.<ref name="gordon00">{{cite web|author=National Climatic Data Center|year=2000|title=Hurricane Gordon Event Report|accessdate=2006-07-29|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~388664|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110519215815/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~388664|archivedate=2011-05-19|df=}}</ref> *June 16, 2001- The subtropical remnant of what was once '''[[Tropical Storm Allison]]''' passes just to the southeast of the state. The storm drops moderate amounts of rainfall, peaking at 4.2 inches (107 mm) in [[Greenwood, Delaware|Greenwood]], which results in drainage problems yet little damage.<ref name="allison01">{{cite web|author=National Climatic Data Center |year=2000 |title=Tropical Storm Allison Event Report |accessdate=2006-07-29 |url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~423153 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071222030800/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~423153 |archivedate=December 22, 2007 }}</ref> *September 11, 2001- '''[[Hurricane Erin (2001)|Hurricane Erin]]''' generates rough surf and rip currents along [[Delaware beaches]], forcing restrictions and closures.<ref name="erin01">{{cite web|author=National Climatic Data Center|year=2000|title=Hurricane Erin Event Report|accessdate=2006-07-29|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~423185|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110519215839/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~423185|archivedate=2011-05-19|df=}}</ref> *July 3, 2003- The remnants of '''[[Tropical Storm Bill (2003)|Tropical Storm Bill]]''' cross over the state, dropping light rainfall of around 1 inch (25 mm).<ref name="bill2003">{{cite web|author=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center|year=2005|title=Rainfall information for Tropical Storm Bill|accessdate=2006-07-29|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/bill2003.html}}</ref> *September 15, 2003- Moisture from the remnants of '''[[Tropical Storm Henri (2003)|Tropical Storm Henri]]''' produce heavy rainfall over portions of Delaware, including a peak of 9.02 inches (229 mm) in [[Hockessin, Delaware|Hockessin]]. The flooding damages hundreds of houses, and traps motorists in submerged vehicles. Several bridges are destroyed or damaged due to rising flood waters, including the [[Red Clay Creek]] which peaks at 17.27 feet (5.2 m). Damage totals $16.1 million (2003 USD, $18.9 million 2008 USD).<ref name="henri03">{{cite web|author=National Climatic Data Center|year=2003|title=Tropical Storm Henri Event Report|accessdate=2006-07-29|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~494478|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110519212619/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~494478|archivedate=2011-05-19|df=}}</ref> Due to the damage, President [[George W. Bush]] declares the state a disaster area.<ref name="henridecla">{{cite web|author=FEMA|year=2003|title=Tropical Storm Henri Delaware Declaration|accessdate=2006-07-29|url=http://www.fema.gov/news/event.fema?id=2446|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060926003934/http://www.fema.gov/news/event.fema?id=2446|archivedate=2006-09-26|df=}}</ref> *September 17, 2003- '''[[Hurricane Isabel]]''' passes to the southwest of the state as it makes landfall on [[North Carolina]]. In the days preceding its landfall, Isabel produces strong waves, and upon striking land, the storm causes a 5-foot (1.5 m) storm surge along the Delaware coast. The waves and surge result in beach erosion and overwash. The outer rainbands of Isabel drop around 1 inch (25 mm) of rain, though the storm's large circulation produces strong wind gusts of up to 70 mph (112 km/h). The wind gusts knock down many trees and power lines, causing one of the worst power outages for [[Pepco Holdings|Conectiv Energy]]. Damage totals to $17.8 million (2003 USD, $20.9 million 2008 USD).<ref name="isabel03">{{cite web|author=National Climatic Data Center|year=2003|title=Hurricane Isabel Event Report|accessdate=2006-07-29|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~494484|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110519215852/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~494484|archivedate=2011-05-19|df=}}</ref> Due to the damage, President Bush declares the entire state a disaster area.<ref name="isabeldecla">{{cite web|author=FEMA|year=2003|title=Hurricane Isabel Delaware Declaration|accessdate=2006-07-29|url=http://www.fema.gov/news/event.fema?id=2429|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060926003958/http://www.fema.gov/news/event.fema?id=2429|archivedate=2006-09-26|df=}}</ref> [[Image:Jeanne Tornado Damage.JPG|right|thumb|Tornado damage from [[Hurricane Jeanne]]]] *August 3, 2004- Heavy surf from '''[[Hurricane Alex (2004)|Hurricane Alex]]''' injures three in Rehoboth Beach. The rough waters result in rescues, as well.<ref name="alex04">{{cite web|author=National Climatic Data Center|year=2004|title=Hurricane Alex Event Report|accessdate=2006-07-29|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~533935|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110519215905/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~533935|archivedate=2011-05-19|df=}}</ref> *August 12, 2004- The remnants of '''[[Tropical Storm Bonnie (2004)|Tropical Storm Bonnie]]''' produce heavy rainfall of over 3 inches (76 mm). The rainfall leads to flooded rivers and roads, forcing the evacuation of 100 people in [[Delaware City, Delaware|Delaware City]].<ref name="bonnie04">{{cite web|author=National Climatic Data Center|year=2004|title=Tropical Storm Bonnie Event Report|accessdate=2006-07-29|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~533937|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110519220013/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~533937|archivedate=2011-05-19|df=}}</ref> *August 30, 2004- Moisture from '''[[Hurricane Gaston (2004)|Hurricane Gaston]]''' drops moderate amounts of rainfall, leading to minor stream and drainage flooding.<ref name="gaston04">{{cite web|author=National Climatic Data Center|year=2004|title=Tropical Storm Gaston Event Report|accessdate=2006-07-29|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~533940|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110519220207/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~533940|archivedate=2011-05-19|df=}}</ref> *September 3, 2004- The combination of swells from '''[[Hurricane Frances]]''' and a high pressure system causes rip currents along the Delaware coastline.<ref name="frances04">{{cite web|author=National Climatic Data Center|year=2004|title=Hurricane Frances Event Report|accessdate=2006-07-29|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~533941|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110519220221/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~533941|archivedate=2011-05-19|df=}}</ref> *September 18, 2004- The remnants of '''[[Hurricane Ivan]]''' produce heavy rainfall for a few hours, causing creek flooding and drainage problems. Damage is minimal.<ref name="ivan04">{{cite web|author=National Climatic Data Center|year=2004|title=Hurricane Ivan Event Report|accessdate=2006-07-29|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~533942|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110519220710/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~533942|archivedate=2011-05-19|df=}}</ref> *September 28, 2004- The remnants of '''[[Hurricane Jeanne]]''', combined with two cold fronts, produce heavy rainfall peaking at 8.01 inches (203 mm) in [[Newark, Delaware|Newark]]. The precipitation leads to rising rivers, including the Red Clay Creek which crests at 13.59 feet (4.14 m) The rainfall also floods roads in the northern portion of the state, resulting in trapped vehicles.<ref name="jeanne04">{{cite web|author=National Climatic Data Center|year=2004|title=Hurricane Jeanne Event Report|accessdate=2006-07-30|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~533943|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110519220906/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~533943|archivedate=2011-05-19|df=}}</ref> The remnants of Jeanne also spawn an [[Fujita scale|F2]] tornado in northern [[New Castle County, Delaware|New Castle County]]. The tornado's 5 mile (8 km) path includes moving through the [[New Castle Airport]] and several buildings. The tornado damages numerous planes and buildings at the airport and injures five people. Damage totals to around $1 million (2004 USD).<ref name="jeanne04torn">{{cite web|author=National Climatic Data Center|year=2004|title=Hurricane Jeanne Event Report (2)|accessdate=2006-07-30|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~533944|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110519220945/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~533944|archivedate=2011-05-19|df=}}</ref> *July 8, 2005- The extratropical remnants of '''[[Hurricane Cindy (2005)|Hurricane Cindy]]''' move through the state, producing heavy rainfall of up to 4.55 inches (116 mm) in [[Delmar, Delaware|Delmar]]. The combination of rain and 20 to 30 mph (32 to 48 km/h) wind gusts down a few weak trees, leaving around 100 without power in New Castle County.<ref name="cindy05">{{cite web|author=National Climatic Data Center|year=2005|title=Hurricane Cindy Event Report|accessdate=2006-07-30|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~573821|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110519221028/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~573821|archivedate=2011-05-19|df=}}</ref> *Mid-July, 2005- The outer rainbands of '''[[Hurricane Dennis]]''' drop light precipitation of around 1 inch (25 mm) throughout the state.<ref name="dennis05">{{cite web|author=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center|year=2005|title=Rainfall information for Hurricane Dennis|accessdate=2006-07-30|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/dennis2005.html}}</ref> *September 16, 2005- Rip currents are caused by '''[[Hurricane Ophelia (2005)|Hurricane Ophelia]]''' passing to the southeast of the state.<ref name="ophelia05">{{cite web|author=National Climatic Data Center|year=2005|title=Hurricane Ophelia Event Report|accessdate=2006-07-30|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~573838|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110519221133/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~573838|archivedate=2011-05-19|df=}}</ref> *October 7, 2005- '''[[Tropical Storm Tammy (2005)|Tropical Storm Tammy]]''' contributes to the '''[[Northeast U.S. flooding of October 2005]]''', which results in heavy rainfall of up to 5.3 inches (134 mm) in [[Lincoln, Delaware|Lincoln]]. The rainfall causes drainage problems and crop damage.<ref name="tammy05">{{cite web|author=National Climatic Data Center|year=2005|title=Tropical Storm Tammy Event Report|accessdate=2006-07-30|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~573840|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110519221201/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~573840|archivedate=2011-05-19|df=}}</ref> *October 24, 2005- The combination of '''[[Hurricane Wilma]]''' and a [[Nor'easter]] produce heavy surf, high tides, and beach erosion along the coastline.<ref name="wilma05">{{cite web|author=National Climatic Data Center|year=2005|title=Hurricane Wilma Event Report|accessdate=2006-07-30|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~573844|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110519221222/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~573844|archivedate=2011-05-19|df=}}</ref> *June 14, 2006- The extratropical remnants of '''[[Tropical Storm Alberto (2006)|Tropical Storm Alberto]]''' drop light rain in the southeastern portion of the state.<ref name="Mid Atl"/> *September 1, 2006- The combined effects of '''[[Hurricane Ernesto (2006)|Tropical Storm Ernesto]]''' and a large high-pressure system leave about 151,000 without power and several trees damaged from strong winds. The system also drops moderate rainfall peaking at 5.15 inches (129 mm) in Jones Crossing; one person requires assistance to be rescued from a flooded roadway.<ref name="ernestoncdc">{{cite web|author=National Climatic Data Center|year=2006|title=Hurricane Ernesto Event Report|accessdate=2007-04-14|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~612799|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110519231251/http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~612799|archivedate=2011-05-19|df=}}</ref> *June 4, 2007- The remnants of '''[[Tropical Storm Barry (2007)|Tropical Storm Barry]]''' dropped light rainfall in the state.<ref name="Mid Atl"/> *September 6, 2008- '''[[Hurricane Hanna (2008)|Tropical Storm Hanna]]''' produces heavy rain and strong winds in the state. Minor tidal flooding is reported in the Delaware Bay.<ref>{{cite web|author=National Climatic Data Center|title=Tropical Storm Hanna Event Report|year=2009|publisher=|accessdate=2009-02-20|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~741265}}{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
===2010s=== * August 27–28, 2011- '''[[Hurricane Irene (2011)|Hurricane Irene]]''' brings heavy rain to the state, a high of {{convert|10.43|in|mm}} is recorded in [[Ellendale, Delaware|Ellendale]], with a tornado in [[Lewes, Delaware|Lewes]] causing damage to about 50 homes and destroying one. Two fatalities can be attributed to the storm in the state.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.delawareonline.com/article/20110829/NEWS/110829002/Updated-rainfall-totals?odyssey=mod|title=Updated rainfall totals|author=The News Journal|date=August 29, 2011|publisher=DelawareOnline|accessdate=September 6, 2011}}</ref><ref name=do>{{cite web|accessdate=2011-08-29|title=Irene leaves flooding, wind damage in its path|publisher=[[The News Journal]]|date=2011-08-25|url=http://www.delawareonline.com/article/20110827/NEWS/110827032/Irene-leaves-flooding-wind-damage-its-path }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.delmarvanow.com/article/20110831/NEWS01/110831026/IRENE-NWS-says-tornado-hit-near-Lewes-95-mph-winds|title=IRENE: NWS says tornado hit near Lewes with 95 mph winds|date=August 31, 2011|publisher=DelmarvaNow.com|location=Salisbury, Maryland|accessdate=August 31, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130801155132/http://www.delmarvanow.com/article/20110831/NEWS01/110831026/IRENE-NWS-says-tornado-hit-near-Lewes-95-mph-winds|archivedate=August 1, 2013|df=}}</ref> * September 7–10, 2011- The remnants of '''[[Tropical Storm Lee (2011)|Tropical Storm Lee]]''' move over the east coast, resulting in strong winds and heavy rain.<ref>{{cite web|title=Tropical Storm Lee remnants drench East Coast|url=http://www.cnn.com/2011/US/09/07/weather.lee/index.html|publisher=the CNN Wire Staff|accessdate=8 October 2012}}</ref> * October 28-November 1, 2011- '''[[Hurricane Rina]]''' did not affect the United States directly, but its remnants joined with a large cold front to fuel the [[2011 Halloween nor'easter]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Thousands in dark week after nor'easter|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/45177254/ns/weather/t/thousands-dark-week-after-noreaster/#.UHMAQo7pQ2k|publisher=msnbc.com staff and news service reports|accessdate=8 October 2012}}</ref> * September 1–4, 2012- The remnants of '''[[Hurricane Isaac (2012)|Hurricane Isaac]]''' move over the eastern coast, causing heavy rains over Delaware and other east coast states.<ref>{{cite web|title=Storm Isaac moves east while impact lingers in Louisiana|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2012-09-02/news/sns-rt-us-storm-isaacbre87l0ph-20120822_1_louisiana-flood-protections-hurricane-isaac|publisher=Tim Ghianni and Edith Honan|accessdate=8 October 2012}}</ref> * October 29–30, 2012 - '''[[Hurricane Sandy]]''' affects the entire state. * September 19, 2017 - Waves from '''[[Hurricane Jose (2017)|Hurricane Jose]]''' cause coastal flooding in Delaware.<ref name=wboc91917>{{cite news|last=Overturf|first=Madeleine|title=Waves from Hurricane Jose Breach Dune, Flood Route One|publisher=WBOC-TV|location=Salisbury, MD|date=September 19, 2017|url=http://www.wboc.com/story/36405606/waves-from-hurricane-jose-breach-dune-flood-route-one|accessdate=September 19, 2017}}</ref>
==Listed by month== Since 1749, 108 tropical cyclones, including some that became extratropical, have affected the state. Most have occurred in September, which coincides with the peak of the [[North Atlantic tropical cyclone|Atlantic hurricane]] season.
{{bar graph|float=center | title = Number of recorded storms affecting Delaware | data_max = 50 | label_type = Month | data_type = Number of storms | label6 = June | data6 = 6 | label7 = July | data7 = 9<!--1989's Allison is included here but not in June--> | label8 = August | data8 = 30 | label9 = September | data9 = 45 <!--The 1783 storm is listed here due to unknown occurrence--> | label10 = October | data10 = 18 | label11 = November | data11 = 2 }}
==Deadliest storms== Most tropical cyclones that impact Delaware only cause rainfall or strong waves, though a few have caused deaths in the state. Storms that caused deaths in Delaware include:
<center> {| class="wikitable" align="center" |- bgcolor="#CCCCCC" ! Name ! Year ! Number of deaths |- | Unnamed || 1785 || 181 |- | Unnamed || 1879 || "Probably exceed 40" |- | [[Gale of 1878]] || 1878 || 18 |- | Unnamed || 1904 || 8 |- | [[1903 Vagabond hurricane|Vagabond Hurricane]] || 1903 || 5 |- | Unnamed || 1783 || "Several" |- | [[Hurricane Floyd|Floyd]] || 1999 || 2 |- | [[Hurricane Irene (2011)|Irene]] || 2011 || 2 |- | [[Hurricane Hazel|Hazel]] || 1954 || ≥1 |- | [[Hurricane Agnes|Agnes]] || 1972 || 1 |} </center>

Date of closest approach ! revision.text:
'''Buckinghamshire''' is a [[List of counties of the United Kingdom|county]] in south-east England.{{cite web|url=http://www.ons.gov.uk/ons/guide-method/geography/beginner-s-guide/other/nomenclature-of-units-for-territorial-statistics/south-east/index.html|archive-url=http://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/20160105160709/http://www.ons.gov.uk/ons/guide-method/geography/beginner-s-guide/other/nomenclature-of-units-for-territorial-statistics/south-east/index.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=5 January 2016|title=South East (England)|publisher=Office for National Statistics|accessdate=19 April 2016}} Its county town is [[Aylesbury]],{{cite web|url=http://www.visitbuckinghamshire.org/Great-Days-Out/Destinations/aylesbury|title=Aylesbury|publisher=Visit Buckinghamshire|accessdate=19 April 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160426184327/http://www.visitbuckinghamshire.org/Great-Days-Out/Destinations/aylesbury|archivedate=26 April 2016|df=}} and it is surrounded by [[Northamptonshire]] to the north, [[Bedfordshire]], [[Hertfordshire]] and [[Greater London]] to the east, [[Surrey]] and [[Berkshire]] to the south, and [[Oxfordshire]] to the west.{{Cite book|page=189|title=The Ordnance Survey Atlas of Great Britain|publisher=Book Club Associates|location =London, UK|year=1982}} Under [[Buckinghamshire County Council]] there are four districts, [[Aylesbury Vale]], [[Chiltern District|Chiltern]], [[South Bucks]] and [[Wycombe District|Wycombe]], while [[Borough of Milton Keynes|Milton Keynes]] has a separate unitary borough council.{{cite web|url=http://www.countiesinengland.com/|title=Your Guide to the Counties of England|publisher=Counties in England|accessdate=9 December 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161010173247/http://www.countiesinengland.com/|archivedate=10 October 2016|df=}} [[Buckinghamshire]] has an area of 1874 km², and a population of 739,600.{{cite web|url=http://www.essentialtravelguide.com/regional-guides/southern-england/buckinghamshire-travel-guide/buckinghamshire-facts/|title=Buckinghamshire Quick Facts & Figures|publisher=Essential Travel Guide|accessdate=19 April 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160428035914/http://www.essentialtravelguide.com/regional-guides/southern-england/buckinghamshire-travel-guide/buckinghamshire-facts/|archivedate=28 April 2016|df=}} [[Local Nature Reserve]]s (LNRs) are designated by local authorities under the [[National Parks and Access to the Countryside Act 1949]]. The local authority must have a legal control over the site, by owning or leasing it or having an agreement with the owner. LNRs are sites which have a special local interest either biologically or geologically, and local authorities have a duty to care for them. They can apply local [[Byelaws in the United Kingdom|bye-laws]] to manage and protect LNRs.{{cite web|url=https://www.gov.uk/protected-or-designated-areas|title=Protected or designated areas|date=9 April 2013|publisher=Department for Environment, Food & Rural Affairs and Natural England|accessdate=29 July 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504145328/https://www.gov.uk/protected-or-designated-areas|archivedate=4 May 2015|df=}}{{cite web|url=https://www.gov.uk/create-and-manage-local-nature-reserves|title=Local nature reserves: setting up and management|date=2 October 2014|publisher=Department for Environment, Food & Rural Affairs and Natural England|accessdate=29 July 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150704111109/https://www.gov.uk/create-and-manage-local-nature-reserves|archivedate=4 July 2015|df=}} As of July 2016 there are sixteen LNRs in [[Buckinghamshire]].{{cite web|url=http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_results.asp?N=&C=4&Submit=Search|title=Local Nature Reserves: Search Results for Buckinghamshire|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=3 July 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304055030/http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_results.asp?N=&C=4&Submit=Search|archivedate=4 March 2016|df=}}{{efn|Natural England lists a seventeenth Buckinghamshire LNR, Denham Quarry Park, but this appears to be an error. The [[River Colne, Hertfordshire|River Colne]] forms the boundary between Buckinghamshire to the west and the [[London Borough of Hillingdon]] to the east. The Natural England map shows most of Denham Quarry Park east of the river in Hillingdon, in an area which is also designated a London LNR, [[Denham Country Park]].{{cite web |url=http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=0&N=denham&ID=1463 |title=Denham Quarry Park |series=Local Nature Reserves |publisher=Natural England |date=8 June 2015 |accessdate=7 April 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160420171302/http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=0&N=denham&ID=1463 |archivedate=20 April 2016 |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271083176%27|title=Map of Denham Quarry Park|series=Local Nature Reserves|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=7 April {{coord|51.7713 | -0.94634|type:landmark_region:GB|name= Snakemoor}}
{{gbmappingsmall|SP728086 }} |[[Aylesbury Vale]] | |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271083174%27 Map] |[http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=4&N=&ID=1421 Details] |The site became a nature reserve in 1987. It has a hay meadow, woods and a pond. There are over 100 species of flowers and other plants, including [[snowdrop]]s and [[lent lily]], a small native species of daffodil.{{cite web |url=http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=4&N=&ID=1421 |title=Snakemoor |series=Local Nature Reserves |publisher=Natural England |date=23 August 2013 |accessdate=26 March 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304082634/http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=4&N=&ID=1421 |archivedate=4 March 2016 |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://www.haddenham-bucks-pc.gov.uk/about-snakemoor|title=About Snakemoor|publisher=Haddenham Parish Council|accessdate=26 March 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160322031925/http://www.haddenham-bucks-pc.gov.uk/about-snakemoor|archivedate=2016-03-22|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Warren Nature Reserve]] |[[File:Warren Nature Reserve 2.JPG|100px|alt=Warren Nature Reserve]] |{{convert|2.3 |ha|acre}} | [[Wooburn]]
{{coord|51.5835 |-0.68368 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Warren Nature Reserve }}
{{gbmappingsmall|SU913880 }} |[[Wycombe District|Wycombe]] | |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271009924%27 Map] |[http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=4&N=&ID=925 Details] |The [[River Wye, Buckinghamshire|River Wye]] runs along the north-west border of the site, providing a habitat for birds such as [[mallard]]s, herons and kingfishers. The reserve is wooded with a variety of trees such as ash, lime and oak. Animals include badgers, voles, grass snakes, muntjac deer and bats.{{cite web |url=http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=4&N=&ID=925 |title=Warren Nature Reserve |series=Local Nature Reserves |publisher=Natural England |date=8 June 2015 |accessdate=29 February 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304074259/http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=4&N=&ID=925 |archivedate=4 March 2016 |df= }} |- ! scope="row"|[[Whiteleaf Hill]] |[[File:Woodland on the slopes of Whiteleaf Hill - geograph.org.uk - 1458725.jpg|100px|alt=Whiteleaf Hill]] |{{convert|11.0 |ha|acre}} | [[Princes Risborough]]
{{coord| 51.7278 | -0.81125 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Whiteleaf Hill }}
{{gbmappingsmall|SP822039 }} |[[Wycombe District|Wycombe]] |[[Chilterns AONB|CAONB]],{{cite web|url=http://www.chilternsaonb.org/ccbmaps/659/137/whiteleaf-hill-and-whiteleaf-cross.html|title=Whiteleaf Hill and Whiteleaf Cross|publisher=Chilterns Conservation Board|accessdate=29 October 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151018152411/http://www.chilternsaonb.org/ccbmaps/659/137/whiteleaf-hill-and-whiteleaf-cross.html|archivedate=18 October 2015|df=}} [[Scheduled Monument|SM]]{{cite web|url=http://www.buckscc.gov.uk/media/131151/WLX_booklet.pdf|archive-url=http://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/20140713021321/http%3A//www.buckscc.gov.uk/media/131151/WLX_booklet.pdf|dead-url=yes|archive-date=13 July 2014|title=The History of Whiteleaf|publisher=Buckinghamshire County Council|accessdate=29 October 2015}} |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271009272%27 Map] |[http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=4&N=&ID=539 Details] |The southern half of the site is semi-natural beech woodland which dates back to at least 1600. Most of the mature trees were lost during storms in the late twentieth century, but they have been replaced by scrub which is regenerating into forest. Birds include [[whitethroat]]s, and there are butterflies such as the [[Speckled wood (butterfly)|speckled wood]] and the [[Aglais io|peacock]].{{cite web|url=http://www.buckscc.gov.uk/media/131167/WLX_Wildlife.pdf|archive-url=http://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/20140713021404/http%3A//www.buckscc.gov.uk/media/131167/WLX_Wildlife.pdf|dead-url=yes|archive-date=13 July 2014|title=Wildlife|publisher=Buckinghamshire County Council|accessdate=29 October 2015}} |} ==See also== {{commons category|Local Nature Reserves in Buckinghamshire}} *[[List of Sites of Special Scientific Interest in Buckinghamshire]] *[[List of Local Nature Reserves in England]] *[[Berkshire, Buckinghamshire and Oxfordshire Wildlife Trust]] ==Notes== {{notelist}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{Local Nature Reserves in Buckinghamshire}} {{LNR lists}} {{coord|51|50|N|0|50|W|region:GB_type:adm1st|display=title}} {{featured list}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Local Nature Reserves in Buckinghamshire}} [[Category:Local Nature Reserves in Buckinghamshire| ]] [[Category:Lists of Local Nature Reserves|Buckinghamshire]] [[Category:Buckinghamshire-related lists]]

{{GeoGroupTemplate}} [[File:Riodelaplatabasinmap.png|thumb|right|350px|Map showing the Río de la Plata drainage basin and major tributaries]] This is a '''list of [[tributaries]] of the [[Río de la Plata]]''', or rivers of the [[La Plata Basin]]. Tributaries and sub-tributaries are hierarchically listed in order from the mouth of the [[Río de la Plata]] upriver. The terms "right" and "left" indicate on which side of the main stem river a tributary is located, from the perspective of looking downriver, following standard [[Tributary#Terminology|river bank terminology usage]]. Countries are identified in abbreviated form: AR for [[Argentina]], UY for [[Uruguay]], PY or PA for [[Paraguay]], BR for [[Brazil]], and BO for [[Bolivia]]. Major dams are also noted.
